Award.AbstractNarration:
DNA sequences that act to determine where, when, and to what degree genes are expressed are called cis-regulatory elements. It is estimated that these elements outnumber genes over 20 to 1 in the human genome, and it is becoming increasingly clear that much of the morphological diversity we see in nature is related to variation in these elements. This is true for both complex and simple traits, for variation within and between populations, and for changes at micro- and macro-evolutionary time scales. Although variation in the traits of organisms often traces to these elements within the genome, they remain poorly understood relative to protein-coding sequences of the genome. This projects seeks to gain a better understanding of how regulatory elements can drive the adaptation of complex traits. Specifically, the research will characterize the cis-regulatory architecture driving adaptive evolution of wing pattern coloration in Heliconius butterflies, an organismal system that has emerged as an important model for understanding the genomic dynamics of adaptation.

This research will address several fundamental questions including: (1) How are regulatory elements structured around genes that control rapidly evolving, highly variable traits? (2) How does regulatory element structure and activity evolve during the adaptive radiation of complex morphologies? (3) To what degree is similarity in morphology controlled by similarity of regulatory elements? This work will also help develop and adapt important new functional genomics techniques to facilitate the broader study of cis-regulatory elements across species. This project will also engage the public through the production of an IMAX documentary film that will incorporate stop action animations of butterfly wing development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is increasingly apparent that much of the morphological diversity we see in nature can be directly traced to variation in cis-regulatory elements (CREs)–regions of non-coding DNA that play a role in determining where, when, and to what degree genes are expressed. This is true for both complex and simple traits, for variation within and between populations, and for short and long time scales. Though the molecular basis of morphological diversity often traces to these non-coding regions, they are still largely considered to be the “dark matter” of the genome and are poorly understood outside of lab model organisms. There are relatively few case studies where individual CREs have been associated with the origin and/or diversification of specific morphological features, and biologists still lack a general concept of what the cis-regulatory architecture of morphological adaptation looks like. For instance, we know relatively little about the number or type of CREs typically involved, to what degree their structures are modular, how constrained CRE structure is, how constrained genomic positioning of CREs is, what changes in CREs underlie new gene expression patterns, or what the rate and mode of CRE diversification is at different levels of divergence.

In this work Reed et al. exploited the advantages of the Heliconius butterfly system to investigate how CREs has driven morphological adaptation within and between species. The genus Heliconius has been intensely studied for over 150 years, primarily because many of the 42 species in the genus show extensive mimicry-related wing pattern variation. Prior to this study, comparative work suggested that the single transcription factor optix is largely responsible for the adaptation of complex red wing patterns in Heliconius. With this study Reed et al. developed the optix locus into a model to link wing pattern diversification with the functional diversification of CREs. Using emerging methods in chromatin profiling they were able to generate maps of CREs that are active during wing pattern development, and identify specific CREs associated with wing pattern diversity and population structure. Then, by using CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing they were able to test the function of CREs and genes in the optix wing patterning pathway. This work revealed that within species there is significant genome-wide variation in CRE activity, and these patterns of variation coincide with both population structure and wing pattern variation. This work also provides some of the first benchmark genome-wide data on how quickly CREs change within and between populations, and to what extent a mix of ancestral and recently originated CREs contribute to morphological change and convergence. In addition to the new conceptual discoveries this work offers, the technical adaptation of chromatin profiling and CRISPR/Cas9 methods to comparative work in an emerging model organism will be important for facilitating similar research by other research groups.
